Award.AwardTitle: Problems in Enumerative Combinatorics and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project is on enumerative and algebraic combinatorics, a fast developing area in contemporary mathematics. The PI explores a series of interrelated enumeration problems on various combinatorial structures, including permutations, matchings, set partitions, integer sequences, general graphs, and fillings of Ferrers boards and other polyominoes. Throughout mathematics a common and successful approach to studying some objects of interest is to study functions on those objects. In combinatorics such functions are often called combinatorial statistics. This research project emphasizes on the algebraic properties of combinatorial statistics and their connections to other branches of mathematics. The major topics include
(1) developing an algebraic theory for the interpolating families between equidistributed combinatorial statistics,
(2) studying descent sets and descent polynomials for various combinatorial structures and their relations to the emerging field of one-dependent determinantal point processes,
(3) characterizing the crossing and nestings in combinatorial structures with applications in graph optimizations and computational mathematical biology.

The proposed research is in the center of combinatorics, which is a branch of mathematics concerning the existence, enumeration, analysis, and optimization of discrete structures. The investigator uses a combined algebraic and combinatorial approach to investigate properties and statistics of many discrete structures, and brings coherence and unity to the discipline of combinatorics. Results of the proposed research have connections and applications to such classical areas of mathematics as algebra, group representation theory, number theory, and probability theory, as well as more applied subjects, notably computer science, graph encoding and drawing, VLSI design, and mathematical biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The awarded project is on enumerative and algebraic combinatorics, a fast developing area in contemporary mathematics. The principal investigator explored a series of interrelated problems on combinatorial statistics, polynomial systems, special patterns in combinatorial structures, as well as applications in graph optimization, computer science, and engineering. This research had an emphasis on algebraic structures and connections to other areas of mathematics.


The outcomes of this project can be put into two major groups. The first is to introduce a new combinatorial model -- fillings of polyominoes -- to study patterns and statistics in a hierarchy of discrete structures. By considering various shapes, fillings, and degrees of convexity, the PI and her team provided theoretic explanations for the symmetry of monotone patterns and the permutation invariance appeared in many combinatorial structures and statistics. They also used the polyomino model to develop efficient algorithms to compute the moments of a large family of statistics and to characterize extremal structures, such as descents, derangements, and non-crossing and non-nesting configurations. The second group of the main outcomes is from an integrated research of three different areas of mathematics: the combinatorial theory of binomial enumeration, the analytic theory of interpolation polynomials, and the algebraic theory of finite operator calculus. The PI and her team developed a new theory of Goncarov polynomials by extending the classical Goncarov Interpolation problem on a single variable to higher dimensions and replacing the derivative by a system of delta operators. The solutions of the general Goncarov Interpolation problem are represented by the sequence of delta-Goncarov polynomials. Major results include an analytic theory for delta-Goncarov polynomials, a characterization of delta-Goncarov polynomials that form sequences of binomial type, and explicit compact formulas for the delta-Abel polynomials, which are delta-Goncarov polynomials whose associated interpolation grids are linear transformations of the set of lattice points. In addition, the PI and her team established a connection to combinatorial theory by showing that delta-Goncarov polynomials provide a natural algebraic tool to describe phenomena of binomial enumerations and order statistics.


The outcomes of this project contribute significantly to the field of combinatorics by introducing new models and techniques. The PI and her team developed a unified method to study the combinatorics of special patterns and statistics systematically over families of discrete structures. The fine structures and variations of their models reveal the fundamental properties and basic characteristics of many discrete objects. The PI and her team also created new tools and methods in Mathematics by incorporating ideas and techniques from operator algebra and interpolation theory into those of algebraic combinatorics.


The research team of this project integrated research activities into education by organizing seminars and conferences, developing new courses, editing research journals, training graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, and supervising research projects at all levels. Special efforts had been made to recruit students and junior scholars from underrepresented groups. Through these activities the PI’s team established long-term collaborations with faculty and students from higher institutions in United States, Asia, and Europe.
